bestBHT.bht: Keep on having authority, signifying that the servant had well done and approved himself to be an honest and diligent servant. Because he had been faithful in a very little, preaching the pure Gospel of Christ and seeking to please the Lord only, he performed a faithful part to Christ. The reward corresponds with the kingly dignity of the returned Lord, but it is important to note that there is no proportion between what the servant does and what he shall have, emphasizing that it is not of merit but of grace.

Philip Schaff: High as the ministerial office is relatively in this world, in the other (and in comparison with the ‘talents’ even here) it is ‘very little;’ certainly is not the sole channel of blessing to the church.
The reward corresponds with the kingly dignity of the returned Lord.
Archibald T. Robertson: Have thou authority (ισθ εξουσιαν εχων). Periphrastic present active imperative. Keep on having authority.
John Gill: Signifying he had well done, and had approved himself to be an honest, diligent, and laborious servant; who, having the grace of God, which made him a good man, and gifts and abilities, which made him a good minister of Christ, he made a good use them, freely communicated the good things of the Gospel, and being employed in a good work, he performed it well.

Because thou hast been faithful in a very little; had preached the pure Gospel of Christ, and the whole of it, and sought not to please men, but the Lord only; not his own glory, but Christ's; abode by him and his interest, notwithstanding all reproaches and persecutions, and so acted a faithful part to Christ.

From whence it appears, that since there is no proportion between what they do, and what they shall have, that therefore it is not of merit but of grace; and which is expressed in the following clause.

bhtAttempts.bht: Keep on having authority, signifying that the servant had well done and approved himself to be an honest and diligent servant. Because he had been faithful in a very little, preaching the pure Gospel of Christ and seeking to please the Lord only, he performed a faithful part to Christ. The reward corresponds with the kingly dignity of the returned Lord, but it is important to note that there is no proportion between what the servant does and what he shall have, emphasizing that it is not of merit but of grace.

Keep on having authority, signifying that the servant had well done and approved himself to be an honest and diligent servant in preaching the pure Gospel of Christ. He performed a faithful part to Christ by abiding with him and his interest despite reproaches and persecutions. The reward corresponds with the kingly dignity of the returned Lord, but it is important to note that the servant's actions do not merit the reward; it is solely by grace.

Keep on having authority, signifying that the servant had well done and approved himself to be an honest and diligent servant in preaching the pure Gospel of Christ. He performed a faithful part to Christ by abiding with him and his interest despite reproaches and persecutions. The reward corresponds with the kingly dignity of the returned Lord, but it is important to note that the servant's actions do not merit the reward; it is solely by grace.

The command to have thou authority signifies that the servant had done well and proved himself to be an honest and diligent servant who faithfully preached the pure Gospel of Christ. By abiding with Christ and His interests, despite facing reproaches and persecutions, the servant performed a faithful part to Christ. The reward given corresponds with the kingly dignity of the returned Lord but is not earned or merited by the servant's actions. Instead, it is solely a result of God's grace.

The command to have thou authority signifies that the servant had done well and proved himself as a faithful servant. By faithfully preaching the pure Gospel of Christ and abiding with Him despite reproaches and persecutions, the servant demonstrated his devotion to Christ's interests. The reward given reflects the kingly dignity of the returned Lord, underscoring the importance of the servant's faithfulness. It is crucial to emphasize that this reward is not earned but solely a result of God's grace.
